verses.text: Guard your steps when you go to the house of God. Draw near to listen rather than to offer the sacrifice of fools, for they do not know that they do evil.
verses.comment: Emphasizes reverence and humility when approaching God's presence. Listening is valued above ritual, echoing themes later found in James 1:19 and Mark 12:33, highlighting interior conversion over mere external rites. It points towards a spiritual discipline focused on true worship.

verses.text: Do not be quick with your mouth, nor hasty in your heart to utter a word before God. For God is in heaven and you are on earth. Therefore let your words be few.
verses.comment: The passage teaches humility and caution before speaking to God, paralleling Jesus’ instruction about not using many words in prayer (Matt. 6:7). This invites a contemplative attitude when praying, reminiscent of deep meditative and structured prayer practices.

verses.text: For a dream comes with much effort, and a fool's voice with many words.
verses.comment: Contrasts effort and empty chatter, reminding us of the value of prudent speech. The association of dreams and labor connects to Genesis 41, where dreams have significance when interpreted by God’s servant, showing the need for divine guidance over mere verbosity.

verses.text: When you make a vow to God, do not delay in fulfilling it. For He has no pleasure in fools. Fulfill what you vow.
verses.comment: Vows are taken seriously; fulfilling them reflects integrity before God. The tradition of making vows, and the admonition to keep them, connects with Jesus’ teaching on oaths in Matthew 5:33-37, preferring commitment to truth over rash promises.

verses.text: It is better that you should not vow than that you should vow and not fulfill it.
verses.comment: This highlights the seriousness of commitment and cautions against empty promises. It connects to Jesus’ teaching about simply letting your ‘Yes’ be ‘Yes,’ encouraging sincerity and disciplined integrity in spiritual practice.

verses.text: Do not let your mouth lead you into sin, nor say before the messenger that it was a mistake. Why should God be angry at your voice and destroy the work of your hands?
verses.comment: Imparts the need for responsibility in speech and action. The mention of the 'messenger' may refer to the temple official or angelic presence, linking to the concept of accountability, seen further in Luke 12:8-9 and in apostolic teaching about confessing wrongdoing.

verses.text: For when dreams increase and words multiply, there is vanity. But fear God.
verses.comment: There is a warning against excessive speculation and verbose religion, with the clear instruction to ‘fear God,’ which is the foundational principle of wisdom (Ps. 111:10). Recognizing God’s majesty calls for awe and faithful obedience, not empty practices.

verses.text: If you see oppression of the poor, and the denial of justice and righteousness in the province, do not be amazed at the matter. For one official is watched by a higher, and there are higher ones over them.
verses.comment: Addresses the reality of systemic injustice. The hierarchy of officials vaguely echoes a structured system of accountability, reminding believers that ultimate justice is in God's hands and encouraging prayer for those in authority (1 Tim. 2:1-2).

verses.text: But the profit of the land is for all; even the king is served by the fields.
verses.comment: Shows mutual dependence in society: even rulers rely on the fruits of the land. It implies a stewardship over creation, with echoes of Genesis 2:15, suggesting a sense of common good and the right use of earthly blessing.

verses.text: He who loves money will not be satisfied with money, nor he who loves abundance with his income. This also is vanity.
verses.comment: Warns against greed, paralleling New Testament teaching (1 Tim. 6:10: ‘love of money is the root of all kinds of evil’). The fleeting satisfaction from earthly riches is contrasted with eternal values.

verses.text: When goods increase, they increase who eat them. And what advantage has their owner except to look at them with his eyes?
verses.comment: Material accumulation attracts dependents, leaving the owner with little true benefit. Echoes of Psalm 39:6, which cautions that mankind heaps up wealth without real profit, inviting deeper reflection on stewardship.

verses.text: The sleep of a worker is sweet, whether he eats little or much. But the abundance of the rich will not let him sleep.
verses.comment: Finds contentment in honest labor, while warning that excess brings anxiety. The restful sleep recalls Proverbs 3:24 and the spiritual wisdom of simplicity over riches, subtly affirming the value of moderation and peace.

verses.text: There is a grievous evil I have seen under the sun: riches kept by their owner to his hurt.
verses.comment: Hoarding wealth becomes self-destructive. Echoes Christ’s teaching in Luke 12:15-21, warning against storing up treasure for oneself instead of being ‘rich toward God’.

verses.text: Riches are lost through misfortune; and when he has a son, there is nothing left in his hand.
verses.comment: Shows how easily wealth can disappear, leaving nothing for heirs. Encourages trust in God’s provision and the importance of legacy centered on spiritual, not material, riches.

verses.text: As he came from his mother’s womb, so he shall go again, naked as he came, and shall take nothing for his labor that he can carry in his hand.
verses.comment: Reminds that no wealth can be taken beyond death. Echoes Job 1:21 and 1 Timothy 6:7, emphasizing eternal perspective over earthly gain. Encourages focus on spiritual preparation and generosity.

verses.text: This also is a grievous evil: that just as he came, so shall he go; and what profit is there to him who labors for the wind?
verses.comment: Reiterates life’s fleeting nature and the futility of striving after temporal gain. This wisdom invites the believer to pursue enduring spiritual virtue, hinting at reward beyond earthly measures.

verses.text: All his days he eats in darkness, with much frustration, sickness, and anger.
verses.comment: Describes the troubled life disconnected from God's peace, reinforcing the call to deeper spiritual fulfillment found in walking according to divine wisdom rather than mere pursuit of wealth.

verses.text: Behold, what I have seen to be good and fitting is to eat and drink and find enjoyment in all the labor in which one labors under the sun during the few days of his life that God gives him. For this is his lot.
verses.comment: Affirms the gift of enjoying life's simple blessings as providential. The acceptance of one’s ‘lot’ in life reflects gratitude, parallel to Paul’s call in Philippians 4:11-13 to find contentment in whatever circumstances.

verses.text: Everyone to whom God has given wealth and possessions, and power to eat of it, and to accept his lot and rejoice in his labor—this is a gift from God.
verses.comment: Material blessings are described as gifts. The power to enjoy them is given by God, not earned, paralleling James 1:17's affirmation that 'every good gift is from above.' This suggests a call toward gratitude and responsible stewardship.

verses.text: For he will not often reflect deeply on the days of his life, because God keeps him occupied with joy in his heart.
verses.comment: God gives abiding joy that surpasses anxiety about life’s brevity or difficulties. This reveals something of the spiritual pleasure found in a life ordered toward God, foreshadowing Christ’s promise of inner peace (John 14:27).
